sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Anthrax: 500 mg orally twice daily for 60 days (guideline dosing)
  • Bacterial conjunctivitis: (Ophthalmic solution) 1 to 2 drops into conjunctival sac(s) every 2 hours while awake for 2 days, then 1 to 2 drops every 4 hours while awake for 5 days
  • Bacterial conjunctivitis: (Ophthalmic ointment) Apply one-half inch ribbon into conjunctival sac 3 times daily for the first 2 days, then 2 times daily for the next 5 days.
  • Bacterial prostatitis, chronic: 500 mg orally every 12 hours for 28 days
  • Bronchitis, chronic, acute exacerbations: Mild/moderate, 500 mg orally every 12 hours for 7 to 14 days
  • Bronchitis, chronic, acute exacerbations: Severe/complicated, 750 mg orally every 12 hours for 7 to 14 days
  • Chancroid: 500 mg orally twice a day for 3 days (guideline dosing)
  • Corneal ulcer: (Ophthalmic solution) 2 drops in the affected eye(s) every 15 minutes for the first 6 hours, then 2 drops every 30 minutes for the remainder of first day; day two, 2 drops every hour; days 3 through 14, two drops every 4 hours
  • Gonorrhea: Uncomplicated, 250 mg orally as a single dose; fluoroquinolones are no longer recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in the United States for the treatment of gonorrhea
  • Granuloma inguinale: 750 mg orally twice daily for at least 21 days and complete healing of lesions (guideline dosing)
  • HIV infection - Salmonella gastroenteritis: (Mild disease with or without symptomatic bacteremia) 500 to 750 mg orally twice daily; duration of 7 to 14 days if CD4+ count is at least 200/mcL, 2 to 6 weeks if CD4+ count is less than 200/mcL; treat for 6 months or greater if recurrent symptomatic septicemia
  • Infection of bone - Infectious disorder of joint: Mild/moderate, 500 mg orally every 12 hours for 4 to 6 weeks
  • Infection of bone - Infectious disorder of joint: Severe/complicated, 750 mg orally every 12 hours for 4 to 6 weeks
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue: Mild/moderate, 500 mg orally every 12 hours for 7 to 14 days
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue: Severe/complicated, 750 mg orally every 12 hours for 7 to 14 days
  • Infectious diarrheal disease: 500 mg orally every 12 hours for 5 to 7 days
  • Infectious disease of abdomen, complicated: 500 mg orally every 12 hours for 7 to 14 days, in combination with metronidazole
  • Infective endocarditis: (Native valve, culture-negative) 500 mg orally every 12 hours, in combination with vancomycin 15 mg/kg IV every 12 hours AND gentamicin sulfate 1 mg/kg IV/IM every 8 hours, for 4 to 6 weeks
  • Infective endocarditis: (Prosthetic valve [late, more than 1 year], culture-negative) 500 mg orally every 12 hours, in combination with vancomycin 15 mg/kg IV every 12 hours AND gentamicin sulfate 1 mg/kg IV/IM every 8 hours, for 4 to 6 weeks AND rifampin 300 mg IV or orally every 8 hours for 6 weeks
  • Infective endocarditis: (Native and prosthetic valve endocarditis caused by HACEK microorganisms) 500 mg orally every 12 hours for 4 to 6 weeks
  • Inhalational anthrax, Postexposure; Prophylaxis: 500 mg orally every 12 hours for at least 60 days
  • Lower respiratory tract infection: Mild/moderate, 500 mg orally every 12 hours for 7 to 14 days
  • Lower respiratory tract infection: Severe/complicated, 750 mg orally every 12 hours for 7 to 14 days
  • Otitis externa, acute: 0.25 mL (entire single-user container) into affected ear every 12 hours for 7 days
  • Plague: Bioterrorism setting, 500 mg orally twice daily for 10 days (guideline dosing)
  • Plague: Postexposure prophylaxis, 500 mg orally twice daily for 7 days (guideline dosing)
  • Pyelonephritis, acute, Uncomplicated: 500 mg orally twice daily for 7 days with or without initial dose of 400 mg IV (guideline dosing)
  • Sinusitis, acute, Mild to moderate: 500 mg orally every 12 hours for 10 days
  • Tularemia, In a mass casualty (bioterrorism) setting or postexposure prophylaxis: 500 mg orally twice daily for 14 days (guideline dose)
  • Typhoid fever: 500 mg orally every 12 hours for 10 days
  • Urinary tract infectious disease: (Regular-release tablets, acute/uncomplicated infection) 250 mg orally every 12 hours for 3 days
  • Urinary tract infectious disease: (Regular-release tablets, mild to moderate infection) 250 mg orally every 12 hours for 7 to 14 days
  • Urinary tract infectious disease: (Regular-release tablets, severe/complicated infection) 500 mg orally every 12 hours for 7 to 14 days
  • Urinary tract infectious disease: (Extended-release tablets, uncomplicated infection) 500 mg orally once daily with the evening meal for 3 days

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• Not approved in children younger than 18 years except for treatment of anthrax and complicated urinary tract infections and pyelonephritis
  • Otic solution and ophthalmic solution are not approved in children younger than 1 year.
  • Anthrax: 10 to 15 mg/kg IV (MAX, 400 mg/dose) or orally (MAX, 500 mg/dose) every 12 hours for 60 days (guideline dosing)
  • Bacterial conjunctivitis: (Ophthalmic solution, 1 year or older) 1 to 2 drops into conjunctival sac(s) every 2 hours while awake for 2 days, then 1 to 2 drops every 4 hours while awake for 5 days
  • Bacterial conjunctivitis: (Ophthalmic ointment, 2 years or older) Apply one-half inch ribbon into conjunctival sac 3 times daily for the first 2 days, then 2 times daily for the next 5 days.
  • Corneal ulcer: (Ophthalmic solution, 1 year or older) 2 drops in the affected eye(s) every 15 minutes for the first 6 hours, then 2 drops every 30 minutes for the remainder of first day; day 2, two drops every hour; days 3 through 14, two drops every 4 hours
  • Cystic fibrosis: 20 to 30 mg/kg/day orally in 2 divided doses
  • Infective endocarditis: (Native valve, culture-negative) 10 to 15 mg/kgorally (MAX, 500 mg) every 12 hours, in combination with vancomycin 40 mg/kg/day IV in 2 or 3 equally divided doses AND gentamicin sulfate 1 mg/kg IV/IM every 8 hours, for 4 to 6 weeks
  • Infective endocarditis: (Prosthetic valve [late, more than 1 year], culture-negative) 10 to 15 mg/kg orally (MAX dose 500 mg) every 12 hours, in combination with vancomycin 40 mg/kg/day IV in 2 or 3 equally divided doses AND gentamicin sulfate 1 mg/kg IV/IM every 8 hours, for 4 to 6 weeks AND rifampin 20 mg/kg/day IV or ORALLY in 3 equally divided doses for 6 weeks
  • Infective endocarditis: (Native and prosthetic valve endocarditis caused by HACEK microorganisms) 10 to 15 mg/kg orally (MAX dose 500 mg) every 12 hours for 4 to 6 weeks
  • Inhalational anthrax, Postexposure; Prophylaxis: 15 mg/kg orally every 12 hours for at least 60 days; MAX 500 mg/dose
  • Otitis externa, acute: (1 year or older) 0.25 mL (entire single-user container) into affected ear every 12 hours for 7 days
  • Plague: Bioterrorism setting, 15 mg/kg (MAX, 500 mg/dose) orally twice daily for 10 days (guideline dosing)
  • Plague: Postexposure prophylaxis, 15 mg/kg (MAX, 500 mg/dose) orally twice daily for 7 days (guideline dosing)
  • Pyelonephritis, Complicated, due to Escherichia coli: (1 to 17 years of age) 10 to 20 mg/kg orally every 12 hours for 10 to 21 days; MAX 750 mg/dose
  • Tularemia, In a mass casualty (bioterrorism) setting or postexposure prophylaxis: 15 mg/kg (MAX 500 mg/dose) orally twice daily for 14 days (guideline dose)
  • Urinary tract infectious disease: (Regular-release tablets, 1 to 17 years, severe/complicated infection) 10 to 20 mg/kg (MAX, 750 mg/dose) orally every 12 hours for 10 to 21 days

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• Renal impairment, CrCl 30 to 50 mL/min: 250 to 500 mg ORALLY every 12 hours (regular-release)
  • Renal impairment, CrCl 5 to 29 mL/min: 250 to 500 mg ORALLY every 18 hours (regular-release)
  • (Extended-release) renal impairment: No adjustment necessary for uncomplicated urinary tract infection
  • (Extended-release) renal impairment, CrCl less than 30 mL/min and complicated urinary tract infection or acute uncomplicated pyelonephritis: 500 mg ORALLY every 24 hours
  • Hemodialysis/peritoneal dialysis: 250 to 500 mg ORALLY every 24 hours, after dialysis
  • (Extended-release) hemodialysis/peritoneal dialysis: MAX: 500 mg ORALLY every 24 hours, administer after hemodialysis or peritoneal dialysis session

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Bacterial conjunctivitis
  • Bacterial prostatitis, chronic
  • Bronchitis, chronic, acute exacerbations
  • Corneal ulcer
  • Gonorrhea
  • Infection of bone - Infectious disorder of joint
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue
  • Infectious diarrheal disease
  • Infectious disease of abdomen, complicated
  • Inhalational anthrax, Postexposure; Prophylaxis
  • Lower respiratory tract infection
  • Otitis externa, acute
  • Pyelonephritis, Complicated, due to Escherichia coli
  • Sinusitis, acute, Mild to moderate
  • Typhoid fever
  • Urinary tract infectious disease
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Anthrax
  • Antibiotic enterocolitis
  • Atypical mycobacterial infection
  • Chancroid
  • Cholangitis
  • Cholera
  • Crohn's disease
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Disease caused by rickettsiae
  • Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography
  • Febrile neutropenia; Treatment and Prophylaxis
  • Granuloma inguinale
  • Helicobacter pylori gastrointestinal tract infection, Triple therapy
  • HIV infection - Salmonella gastroenteritis
  • Infection by Yersinia enterocolitica
  • Infective cholangitis - Sepsis
  • Infective endocarditis
  • Meningococcal infectious disease
  • Operation on gastrointestinal tract, Colorectal - Postoperative infection; Prophylaxis
  • Otorrhea (Chronic)
  • Peritonitis
  • Plague
  • Providencia stuartii infection
  • Pyelonephritis, acute, Uncomplicated
  • Salmonella carrier
  • Spotted fevers
  • Stenotrophomonas maltophilia infection, Pseudomonas maltophilia
  • Transrectal biopsy of prostate
  • Transurethral resection of the prostate
  • Tuberculosis
  • Tularemia, In a mass casualty (bioterrorism) setting or postexposure prophylaxis

mono.title: Black Box Warning
mono.mono:
Oral (Tablet, Extended Release; Tablet)
Fluoroquinolones, including ciprofloxacin hydrochloride, are associated with an increased risk of tendinitis and tendon rupture in all ages. Risk further increases with age over 60 years, concomitant steroid therapy, and in kidney, heart, or lung transplant recipients. Fluoroquinolones, including ciprofloxacin hydrochloride, may exacerbate muscle weakness in persons with myasthenia gravis. Avoid in patients with known history of myasthenia gravis.

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• concomitant tizanidine administration
  • hypersensitivity to ciprofloxacin, other quinolones, or any product component

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• myasthenia gravis; may exacerbate muscle weakness; ventilatory support requirement and death have been reported; avoid use
  • tendinitis and tendon rupture have been reported; may occur bilaterally, within first 48 hours, during, or several months after completing therapy; increased risk with age over 60 years, concomitant steroid therapy, and in kidney, heart, or lung transplant recipients; drug discontinuation recommended for tendon pain, swelling, inflammation, or rupture
  • alkalinized urine; may result in crystalluria
  • concurrent administration of theophylline should be avoided; if concomitant use is necessary, monitoring and dosage adjustment may be required
  • concomitant use with milk products or calcium-fortified juices alone should be avoided
  • convulsions, increased intracranial pressure, and toxic psychosis have been reported; increased risk with known or suspected CNS disorders (eg, epilepsy, severe cerebral arteriosclerosis) or other risk factors (eg, renal dysfunction, certain drug therapy) that may predispose to seizures or lower the seizure threshold
  • elderly patients; increased risk of QT prolongation
  • hepatotoxicity, severe (eg, hepatic necrosis, hepatic failure) and sometimes fatal, has been reported; onset is rapid (range, 1 to 39 days) and often associated with hypersensitivity; increased risk for fatal outcomes in patients older than 55 years; discontinue use immediately if hepatitis is suspected
  • hypersensitivity and/or anaphylactic reactions have occurred, including serious and occasionally fatal reactions; discontinue therapy at first sign of skin rash, jaundice, or any other sign of hypersensitivity
  • overgrowth of resistant organisms, including yeast and fungi, may occur; reevaluate treatment if no response after 1 week of therapy (otic)
  • pediatric patients; increased risk for adverse events related to joints and surrounding tissues
  • peripheral neuropathy has been reported with oral and injectable fluoroquinolones; may occur any time during therapy and persist for months to years or become permanent even after discontinuation; if symptoms occur, discontinue use and switch to a non-fluoroquinolone unless benefit outweighs risk
  • phototoxicity/photosensitivity, moderate or severe, may occur; avoid excessive exposure to sunlight or UV light; discontinue if phototoxicity occurs
  • physical activity, strenuous; may increase risk of tendon rupture
  • QT-interval prolongation, including rare cases of torsade de pointes, has been reported; avoid use with known QT prolongation, uncorrected hypokalemia, and with class IA (quinidine, procainamide), or class III (amiodarone, sotalol) antiarrhythmic agents
  • renal dysfunction; may increase risk of seizures and tendon rupture (with renal failure)
  • renal impairment; dosage adjustment necessary
  • sensory or sensorimotor axonal polyneuropathy have been reported; discontinue therapy if patient experiences symptoms of neuropathy
  • tendon disorders, such as rheumatoid arthritis, history of; may increase risk of tendon rupture
  • report suspected adverse reactions to the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• Ciprofloxacin: AAP: Maternal medication usually compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Ciprofloxacin: WHO: Avoid breastfeeding.
  • Ciprofloxacin: Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.

mono.title: Adverse Effects
mono.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Rash
  • Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea, Nausea
  • Neurologic:Dizziness
  • Otic:Application site pain (2% to 3%, otic), Pruritus (2% to 3%, otic)
  • Psychiatric:Restlessness
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Prolonged QT interval, Torsades de pointes
  • Immunologic:Hypersensitivity reaction, Serious (rare)
  • Musculoskeletal:Myasthenia gravis, Exacerbation, Rupture of tendon, Tendinitis
  • Neurologic:Peripheral neuropathy, Raised intracranial pressure, Seizure
  • Psychiatric:Drug-induced psychosis (rare)
  • Renal:Acute renal failure, Hemorrhagic cystitis

mono.title: Mechanism Of Action
mono.mono: Ciprofloxacin hydrochloride is a fluoroquinolone which has broad-spectrum antibacterial action. It prevents bacterial DNA replication, repair, transcription, and recombination by inhibiting topoisomerase II (DNA gyrase) and topoisomerase IV (both Type II topoisomerases).

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Oral, extended-release tablet: time to peak concentration, 2.3 h to 4.5 h (mean)
  • Oral, tablet: time to peak concentration, 1 h to 2 h
  • Bioavailability: approximately 70%
  • Effect of food: (extended-release tablet), standard meal increases Cmax by 120% and AUC by 170%, increases Tmax by approximately 4.5 h to 7 h, fasting lowers bioavailability
  • Effect of food: (tablet), delays absorption from 1 h to 2 h
  • Effect of food: (suspension), none

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono: Ciprofloxacin HCl, Metabolites: desethyleneciprofloxacin (M1), sulfociprofloxacin (M2), oxociprofloxacin (M3), and formylciprofloxacin (M4)

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Biliary: 1% to 2% as metabolites
  • Fecal: (extended-release tablet), approximately 43% unchanged and as metabolites
  • Fecal: (tablet), approximately 20% to 35%
  • Renal: (extended-release tablet), 26.9% (over 24 h) unchanged and approximately 41% (over 96 h) unchanged and as metabolites
  • Renal: (tablet), 15% as metabolites, approximately 40% to 50% unchanged
  • Dialyzable: yes (hemodialysis), less than 10% removed; yes (peritoneal dialysis), less than 10%

sub.title: Elimination Half Life
sub.mono:
• (extended-release tablet), approximately 4.5 h
  • (tablet), approximately 4 h
  • reduced renal function: slightly prolonged

mono.title: Administration
mono.mono:
• Ophthalmic
    (Ointment) Apply one-half inch ribbon into conjunctival sac
  • Oral
    • Extended-release tablets and immediate-release tablets are not interchangeable.
    • (Extended-release tablets) Swallow whole, do not split, crush or chew.
    • (Tablet and Cipro(R) XR extended-release tablet) Take with or without food; do not take with milk, yogurt, or calcium-fortified juice.
    • (Tablet and Cipro(R) XR extended-release tablet) If given together, take 2 hours before or 6 hours after antacids containing magnesium or aluminum, sucralfate, didanosine buffered tablets or powder for oral solution, other highly buffered drugs, polymeric phosphate binders (eg, sevelamer, lanthanum carbonate), or products containing calcium, iron, or zinc.
    • (Proquin(R) XR extended-release tablet) Take with a main meal, preferably in the evening; do not take with milk, yogurt, or calcium-fortified juice
    • (Proquin(R) XR extended-release tablet) If given together, take at least 4 hours before or 2 hours after antacids containing magnesium or aluminum.
    • (Proquin(R) XR extended-release tablet) If given together, take at least 4 hours before or 2 hours after sucralfate, didanosine buffered tablets or powder for oral solution, or products containing calcium, iron, or zinc.
  • Otic
    • Warm solution by holding container in hands for at least 1 minute
    • Patient should lie with affected ear upward; position should be maintained for at least 1 minute after instillation; repeat in the opposite ear if necessary

mono.title: Monitoring
mono.mono:
• systemic infection: fever, symptomatic improvement
  • otitis externa: cultures may be necessary if infection does not improve after 1 wk of treatment; reduced earache, reduced swelling of external auditory canal, and reduced outer ear tenderness
  • systemic infection: renal function
  • systemic infection: CBC
  • rash or any other sign of hypersensitivity

mono.title: How Supplied
mono.mono:
• Generic
    • Ophthalmic Solution: 0.3 %
    • Oral Tablet: 100 MG, 250 MG, 500 MG, 750 MG
    • Otic Solution: 0.2 %
  • Cetraxal
    Otic Solution: 0.2 %
  • Ciloxan
    • Ophthalmic Ointment: 0.3 %
    • Ophthalmic Solution: 0.3 %
  • Cipro
    Oral Tablet: 250 MG, 500 MG, 750 MG

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
FLUOROQUINOLONES
USES: Fluoroquinolones are bacteriocidal broad spectrum antibiotics. PHARMACOLOGY: Fluoroquinolones inhibit bacterial topoisomerase IV and DNA gyrase enzymes required for DNA replication, transcription, repair and recombination. EPIDEMIOLOGY: Overdose is rare. OVERDOSE: Dizziness, drowsiness, disorientation, slurred speech, nausea and vomiting. ADVERSE EFFECTS: Nausea/vomiting, diarrhea, headache, drowsiness, and insomnia. Seizures, hallucinations, elevated liver enzymes and renal toxicity are rare. Seizures appear related to predisposing factors. Hypersensitivity reactions including anaphylaxis and vasculitis have developed. WITHDRAWAL FROM MARKET: Grepafloxacin was withdrawn from the worldwide market in October, 1999 after reports of cardiovascular toxicity; QT prolongation had been associated with its use. Gatifloxacin was voluntarily withdrawn from the market in May 2006 due to reports of severe hypo- and hyperglycemic events.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
FLUOROQUINOLONES
  • Support: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive.
  • Decontamination: Activated charcoal, gastric lavage
  • Seizure: IV benzodiazepines, barbiturates
  • Monitoring of patient: Monitor liver enzymes and renal function with significant overdose. Monitor fluid & electrolyte status if severe GI effects; CNS function.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
FLUOROQUINOLONES
Unknown. Recommended dose (adults): 300-500 mg BID; contraindicated in children.

mono.title: Clinical Teaching
mono.mono:
• Instruct patient to immediately report symptoms of tendonitis or tendon rupture (pain, swelling, inflammation of tendon), especially if elderly and/or using concomitant steroids.
  • Tell patient to immediately report symptoms of peripheral neuropathy, including pain, burning, tingling, or numbness.
  • Advise patient to use sunscreen, avoid tanning beds, and avoid excessive exposure to sunlight as drug causes phototoxicity.
  • Counsel patient to avoid activities requiring coordination until drug effects are realized, as drug may cause dizziness and lightheadedness.
  • Side effects may include nausea, vomiting, rash, headaches, confusion, or restlessness.
  • Otic side effects may include headaches, ear pain, itching, or local fungal infections.
  • Instruct patient to immediately report severe diarrhea, dermatologic reactions (toxic epidermal necrolysis, Stevens-Johnson), or symptoms of hepatitis.
  • Advise patient to immediately report CNS events (hallucinations, depression, suicidal thoughts, or convulsions).
  • Warn patient to avoid taking drug alone with dairy products (milk, yogurt) or calcium-fortified juice. The drug may be taken with meals that contain these items.
  • Advise patient to take drug 2 hours before or 6 hours after magnesium or aluminum-containing antacids or products containing calcium, iron, or zinc.
  • Ophthalmic: Instruct patient on proper instillation technique and to remove contact lenses prior to use.
  • Advise patient to avoid caffeine during therapy due to enhanced caffeine effects.
